title: TO RIOT
body:
From: Riot Games
Hey KAYN BRINGS PAIN,

Your removed content:

Shut up no one cares what you have to say you ignorant ahole

Rule Violated: Don't Be a Jerk

While we aren't taking any actions against your account at this time, please keep in mind that continued violation of the Boards Universal Rules and sub-board guidelines may result in future punishments.

-- Seras Dragon


Cause i retaliated to a guy that was being rude... guessing riot's staff.

replies.body:
Eh that's debatable.

the definition of staff on google is "all the people employed by a particular organization."

Which they are employed, just as volunteers.

> the definition of staff on google is "all the people employed by a particular organization."

Well, if that's the definition we're using, then it's important to be clear on what it actually means.

Specifically, I'm referring to the use of the term "employed", which, if we're using the definitions Google provides, is defined as "give work to (someone) and pay them for it", which would then mean that the volunteers wouldn't be considered staff as they're not payed.

Point being, it's important to consider where you're getting your definitions from.

*Note: As I understand it, Google defaults to Oxford Dictionary for definitions, though that may not be the case.*
I mean either way you want to slice it, they do work for riot.
Interns and volunteers are not considered staff. Staff is used for payed employment.

Just like you initially stated, that's debatable.

It really depends on where you're getting your definitions from as to whether the term "staff" would include or exclude "volunteers". As in my earlier example, Oxford's definitions for "staff" would exclude volunteers, but if you were to look at something else, namely Cambridge Dictionary, you might find that their definitions do include volunteers (though that's one definition among several and the "American-English" version).

Even when considering "worker" instead, it still seems as though some sources (Oxford, for example) exclude volunteers while others (Cambridge, for example) include them.

even if the conversation wasn't very well presented, the argument over whether banning a teammates pick was valid or if combined with sufficient harassment deserves a report, is quite a contentious debate, with alot of potential for exploration.

Personally I'm still not sure about whether this should be reportable or even bannable. Since whilst banning a champion to deny the enemy team seems perfectly reasonable. Banning out the first pick of the game, and goading a teammate seems like poor sportsmanship and harassment.

A reasonable arguement is that having a pregame report feature should also be available, since I don't want to have to play with that abusive teammate to have the option to report him and protect the rest of the community from such abuse without having to play with the cockroach and lose lp.

Riot's volunteers need to stop being so stuck up and heavy handed. Asking the thread creator to restructure and improve the thread post is a much more appropriate response.

I'm more than a little confused as to the context of your comment. No posts were removed, only his comment. A comment that had no content except "Shut up no one cares what you have to say you ignorant ahole".

Noone was arguing that the discussion was invalid or not worth having. In fact that comment wasn't even on the thread about banning teammate picks, it was on a thread about the punishment system. 

In fact, the guy has only ever had one comment, that was one line and existed solely as an insult, actually removed, ever. How is that heavy handed?

personally I don't care about him, his rude comments are the least of my concerns, such vulgar and unproductive language is very reasonable to censor.

The issue was *everyone else* was discussing the validity of team-self-bans, and the thread started in a very valid fashion. Maybe he ended up being inappropriate, but the initial post starting the thread sparked reasonable discussion, and I'm a little put out, that the rest of the discussion was lost.

I remember the discussion you're talking about, and can't find it so I can only assume it has been deleted, but I assure you it wasn't by a mod. We only delete posts when the content of the post breaks the rules, not the comments. We might lock the thread if things really spiral but we don't delete for that.

the post itself wasn't very high quality but it was a passable start to a good conversation that other members in the community commandeered, and he ranted in the comments, but for the most part we ignored him.

In retrospect his screenshot could be considered name and shame, but again, most of us ignored him and were discussing if say banning a team mates last pick hover Yasou is alright, or if we're first pick, is having our champion banned from us, bannable, and where do we draw the line?

So yeah I guess his post probably broke some rules, and we're just salty that our comments were lost into the drainhole of good comments on posts that were destined to be deleted.

Nothing in the mod actions, if the post was deleted he must have done it himself. None of the name and shame threads that were deleted recently had any comments on them nor were any of them his. OP has only had the one comment deleted, but I have a feeling the post you're referring to wasn't his post...maybe. I can't remember enough about it to find it, I can only tell you it wasn't deleted by a mod.

We typically just edit name and shames but if they use the link field we can't edit that out, so in that scenario the post would be deleted by us yes. Doesn't appear to have been the case here though.
All these clowns that removed your thread are volunteer. They have no affiliation with riot's company on any legal front.
